title: The Analysis Function
body:
The Analysis Function is a cross-government network consisting of around 17,000 people involved in the generation and dissemination of analysis across government and beyond. The head of the Analysis Function is Sir Ian Diamond.

 

The Analysis Function brings together analysts from across different professions, such as statisticians, economists, operational researchers etc, but also includes anyone who produces analysis, evidence or research across government. Read more about some of the different types of analyst below. 

 

The role of the Function (and analysis more widely) is to support government to make stronger, evidence-based decisions so that policy and operations deliver value for money and improve the lives of the people in the UK. With all analysts coming together as an Analysis Function, we can strive towards consistent professional standards of analysis.

title: Scoping the analysis
body:
The scoping stage is essential to ensuring that both parties have a solid understanding of the problem, allowing expectations to be aligned to the possibility of what can realistically be delivered. 

Making sure that the problem is well defined early in the project means that analysis can be much more effective in directly addressing the research needs. In addition, defining this early will improve the efficiency, as there will be less need for changes later in the process. For these reasons, it is key to allow time to engage with analysts early in the project.

_graphic.alt: The analytical cycle; starts with scoping the analysis, then designing the analysis followed by conducting, delivering and disseminating with refinement throughout

title: Summary
body:
A glossary of terms included in this module can be found in the summary document, which you can download on the last page of this course.

More resources

Government Statistical Service guidance on "Communicating, Quality, Uncertainty and Change"

Uncertainty Toolkit for Analysts in Government from the Government Actuary’s Department, particularly the introduction and summary to understand the importance of considering uncertainty.

Advice for policy professionals using statistics: 10 things you really need to know about statistics guidance

Uncertainty and how we measure it for our surveys from the Office for National Statistics

For further information on qualitative methods, the DQHub are currently developing the "Data Collection Fundamentals" course

title: Data linkage
body:
Technological advancements into a data-rich society have resulted in opportunities for data linkage, a methodological process whereby individual's records from multiple data sources are linked together. This allows data from different areas to be linked and analysed, producing findings that maximise data utilisation and provide insights into relationships across areas (such as linking health records with educational outcomes).

 

Sometimes, data linkage methods are simpler, such as when a unique identifier (i.e. NHS number) can be used to match records. In other instances more complicated methods are developed to account for typos, human error or other inconsistences in identifiers. In all linkage methods, some level of error is unavoidable. Linkage error, either incorrectly linking individuals or missing a duplicated individual's records, can affect analysis produced. This again adds another dimension of uncertainty or potential error to analytical findings that must be considered and communicated.

title: Time series
body:
Seasonal adjustment

Seasonal adjustment, frequently used in official statistics, is a technique to remove systematic calendar-related variation associated with the time of year from time series data. For example, seasonal trends in a temperature time series result in lower values in winter months. Removing seasonal variation from data will uncover the underlying trends, enabling an analyst to evaluate whether a specific change may be attributable to a policy change or economic factors rather than a pattern of seasonal variation. For example, by seasonally adjusting temperature data, any increase or other changes in overall temperature by year could be seen (i.e. exploring climate change) despite normal seasonal fluctuations within each year.

title: Government Functional Standard for Analysis
body:
The Government Functional Standard for Analysis has been developed to set a standard expectation for any analysis produced across government, and to develop trust in analytical capability. It brings together guidance and standards from across the 7 professions of the Analysis Function. 

The standard is aimed both at the producers and users of analysis, including non-analysts, particularly regarding their expectations for analysis. The main points applicable to non-analysts are: 

  • "inform Ministers and other leaders from the outset through interdisciplinary working"
  • "the analysis is widely consulted upon, open to and encompasses a range of different perspectives from partners and users of analysis"
  • "the results of the analysis are written and presented so they can be easily understood by, and are useful to, the user"
  • "user needs are responded to while applying analytical best practice, precision and rigour in their work"
  • "that public service codes of conduct and ethics and those of associated professions are upheld"

title: Summary
body:
The purpose of this module is to encourage you to think critically when using data visualisations to draw insights, and to consider using multiple sources of evidence before coming to any conclusions. 

Furthermore, while the information shown in data visualisations may depict a correlation, this should not be confused with causation (where the evidence shows one variable has caused the outcome of another). For example, where you see a change in a measured outcome, this does not necessarily mean the change has been caused by a policy reform, there may be other factors impacting this change too. 

More Resources

AF Data Visualisation Guidelines

Data Visualisation and Accessibility Presentation

Financial Times Visual Vocabulary

ONS presenting data guidelines

Free Course: Exploring data: Graphs and numerical summaries

title: Introduction
body:
Data visualisations are either used for exploratory (gaining familiarity and understanding the dataset, variable or relationship) or explanatory purposes (communicating a particular message). Either way, creating data visualisations should make the data more digestible and easier to understand than picking out the same message from a chunk of text. 

Producers of data visualisations will make decisions about the best ways to display various types of data and communicate insights. The Government Analysis Function have produced best practice guidelines for data visualisations, which should be followed by all analysts and producers of visualisations across government. Broadly, well-made graphs are clear, uncluttered and easy to understand.

All users should be able to pick out key messages as well as think critically about the story or message the visualisation is telling. It is also good practice to use multiple sources of evidence in order to form a conclusion. This is because, sometimes, visualisations may draw attention to particular elements or perpetuate biases. 

Below are some examples of how visualisations may not always portray an objective message, and examples of how they could have followed best practices.

title: Axes & scales
body:
One way in which bad practice may distort the message a visualisation communicates on proportions is by not starting the y-axis (vertical axis) at 0. 

In the below example, Graph A shows good practice, where the y-axis goes from 0 to 100. However, Graph B shows how, despite using the same data, starting the y-axis at 50 has distorted the differences between categories.
instruction: Drag the slider to compare graphs

_beforeafter.altbefore: graph showing employment rates for each UK country
_beforeafter.alt: graph showing employment rates for each UK country with y-axis starting at 50

bottomText:
The differences between bars are exaggerated in Graph B, giving a false impression of the data. For example, the employment rate in Scotland appears around half that of England when actually there is only a 17 percentage point difference. This difference is much more evident in the second graph.

With bar graphs, not starting the axes at 0 disrupts the scale. While the data is the same, the good practice and bad practice chart examples portray different messages about the differences between the four countries.

However, other types of visualisation, such as a line chart, can have an axis start above 0.

title: 3D charts
body:
Using a 3D chart can distort the proportions shown in a graph, particularly in pie or bar charts. 

Below, Graph A shows a pie chart following good practice, using a 2D plot, while Graph B shows how the use of a 3D chart can impact the ease of drawing objective information from a plot.
instruction: Drag the slider to compare the pie charts.

_beforeafter.alt: a 3D pie chart showing favourite colours, which distorts size

bottomText:
The 3D nature of the second chart has distorted the proportions of colours.

At a first glance of Graph B (the 3D chart), it appears as though blue is more popular than red as the blue section appears bigger than red from this angle. This is especially true as Graph B does not include data labels to disprove this observation. 

However, looking at the same data in Graph A (the 2D chart), with data labels, you can see that red was actually marginally more popular than blue, although the difference was small.

Overall, good practice graphs will use 2D charts, not 3D, to better display the proportion of each category.

title: Types of Analyst
body:
Some of the groups of analysts in the Analysis Function are members of a profession. There are 28 professions in the civil service, aiming to bring together similar roles situated in different departments to maintain high standards but also encourage career development. However, not every analyst is part of one of these professions, such as a Data Analyst role. Different types of analysts will produce different forms of analysis, and be able to support you in different ways. 

Expand each section below to learn more about some of the different types of government analysts and the work they do. As the Analysis Function encompasses anyone who performs analysis, there are more roles beyond these which are part of the Function too.

_items.title: Data Analyst
_items.body: Data Analysts collect, organise and study data to provide business insight. Working across a broad range of areas, Data Analysts understand, manipulate and accurately analyse data, providing insight, briefing internal and external audiences in ways that make the complex easy to understand, particularly for non-specialist audiences. They are not connected to a specific Government profession.

_items.title: Economist
_items.body:
There are multiple analyst roles that sit under the Government Economic Service, all part of the Analysis Function. 

A key role of any economic analyst in government is to provide evidence and projections of expected outcomes (and/or losses) from various policy proposals. Typically, evidence will include cost benefit analysis, impact assessments, policy appraisal, forecasting and other statistical analysis.

_items.title: Data Scientists
_items.body:
Data Scientists in government combine statistical methods with computing techniques to use a wide range of data sources to gain deep insights and address complex business problems. A data science team uses a blend of techniques to work with large data, often combining multiple datasets, to gain new, innovative and real-time insights. This enables data science teams to help the organisation understand not just what has happened but why, and what may happen in the future. Data Scientists use their insights to support evidence-based policy making. Government Data Scientists can align to both the Government Analysis Function and the Digital, Data and Technology profession.

Government departments who do not have internal data scientists, may be able to get support from the Data Science Campus who sit within the Office for National Statistics.

_items.title: Social Researcher
_items.body: The Government Social Research profession provide tailored and robust social research insight, advice and evidence. This allows decision makers to understand systems, processes and change associated with people, groups, organisations and society (their attitudes, perceptions, behaviours & intentions) to inform and improve the quality of strategy, policy and delivery decision-making. They provide expertise in applied qualitative and quantitative design and analysis approaches, evaluation, behavioural science and interventions to solve complex problems to ensure decision-making is robust and defensible; providing an understanding of ‘what works, for whom, to what extent, in what contexts, how and why/why not?’

_items.title: Actuaries
_items.body: Actuaries mainly sit within the Government Actuary Department. They provide analysis, prediction and commentary on complex financial problems involving risk and uncertainty to solve financial challenges faced by the UK public sector. They also use their analysis to advise on effective strategies to manage future risks. For example, assessing the costs of the public service pension schemes and modelling the cashflows of the books of student loans sold to the private sector

_items.title: Operational Researchers
_items.body:
Operational Researchers sit within the Government Operational Research Service. They combine knowledge of statistics, data science and mathematics with consultancy skills, stakeholder engagement and consensus building. This allows them to define, model and solve complex real-world problems. 

Analysts offer rigorous, objective and practical analytical support to decision makers before matters become a problem.

_items.title: Statisticians
_items.body:
In government, statisticians sit within the Government Statistical Service (GSS) and generally work in the collection, production and communication of official statistics. They are spread across a whole range of public bodies, including the devolved administrations and UK government departments that produce and analyse statistics. 

The GSS is made up of statisticians, data scientists, researchers, economists, policy experts, business support teams, data journalists, data visualisation experts, methodologists, media experts etc.

_items.title: Geographers
_items.body:
Geographic Analysts, Geographic Advisors and Geospatial Specialists are some of the roles of the Government Geography Profession. 

They collect, collate, manage and link administrative data by geographic reference to enable the analysis of variabilities of government activity on populations as a result of the pre-existing distributions of resources. Government Geographers integrate geographic data within wider analytical work and apply different specialist techniques to account for the geographic dimensions of the data. They communicate analysis effectively, using visualisations.

title: Modelling: Case Study
body:
The Food Standards Agency (FSA) have used modelling techniques to predict outbreaks of norovirus before they happen. 

First of all, they collected tweets that contained words or phrases that were consistent with symptoms of norovirus and excluded words that suggested the symptoms had been caused from other reasons such as "pregnancy" or "hangover".

A model was then created using this data, where changes in the frequency of tweets containing these words or phrases were used to predict a rise in cases. This would then trigger advertising campaigns about symptoms, how to reduce the spread and notify NHS teams that a spike may be imminent. 

The costs of producing this model were relatively low, it required only one analyst's time to maintain. This means that the model only needed to prevent 500 cases (around 0.2% of the annual average) to provide value for money.

title: Data Linkage: Case Study
body:
One example of where data linkage has been used to produce valuable research was a project between the Office for National Statistics (ONS) and the Department of Education (DfE). An evidence gap was identified for researching the impact of personal circumstances on outcomes, particularly for vulnerable children. 

To fill this gap, ONS and DfE will create a 'Growing up in England' (GUIE) dataset using information from Census records and attainment data from schools. Initial linkage has had a 90% linkage rate (rate that observations from DfE data were linked to Census records). 

This linked data can be used in research that investigates the impact of circumstances in early life or demographics on educational outcomes. As a result the analysis could be used, for example, to inform evidence-based policy making or evaluate the impact of policies targeted at improving outcomes for disadvantaged children.

title: Relative vs. Absolute Risk
body:
Some types of analytical outputs, including some forms of modelling, give results in the form of "relative risk"; the likelihood of an event occurring relative to another event, rather than the likelihood of an event occurring overall (the latter of which is called absolute risk). The problem is, relative risks can exaggerate the effect size. A little confusing, but lets put an example to the definition. 

A medical trial report may find that a certain drug reduces the risk of high blood pressure by 20%. This is the relative risk. However, if the absolute risk of having high blood pressure is 2% (or every 20 in 1000 people), then the drug only reduces the risk to 1.6% (16 in 1000 people). It has prevented high blood pressure for every 4 in 1000.

When reporting on this finding, you could use the relative risk, and say the drug reduces the risk by 20% or the absolute risk and say it has prevented every 4 in 1000 cases. While these are both true and come from the same data, they paint quite different pictures around the effect.

title: Relative vs absolute risk
body:
Is the following a relative or absolute risk? 

Children who eat fast food once a week are twice as likely to develop Type 2 diabetes in adulthood.

_items.feedback: The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. A relative risk is the chance of a given event occurring in relation to another event. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.

The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. A relative risk is the chance of a given event occurring in relation to another event. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.

_feedback.correct:
Correct. The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance. 

 

Note: Statistics used are fictional

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.
_incorrect.notFinal: Incorrect. The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.

_partlyCorrect.final: Incorrect. The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Incorrect. The statement provides the risk in relation to those who do not eat fast food. An absolute risk would be: Children who eat fast food once a week have a 26% chance of developing type 2 diabetes in adulthood, while children who do not have a 13% chance.

title: Confidence Intervals
body: Which is the correct definition for a confidence interval?

_items.text: The probability that the true value will fall within that window.
_items.feedback: Incorrect. That is the definition for confidence level, not confidence interval.

_items.text: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between
_items.feedback: That is the correct definition

_items.text: The possibility that the result of a statistical test or model is attributable simply to chance
_items.feedback: Incorrect. That is the definition of statistical significance.

_feedback.correct: Correct. The definition of a confidence interval is: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. The definition of a confidence interval is: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between.
_incorrect.notFinal: Incorrect. The definition of a confidence interval is: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between.

_partlyCorrect.final: Incorrect. The definition of a confidence interval is: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Incorrect. The definition of a confidence interval is: A range of values that the true value of the population is likely to fall between.

title: Sampling
body: The quality of a sample can be affected by...

_items.feedback: Incorrect.
Correct. Sampling frames provide information of all possible participants, if the sampling frame is inaccurate or of low quality, this will impact the quality of the sample too.
Correct. A larger sample increases the probability that all groups/views will be represented.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. Two of the answers were correct: 

  • The sampling frame
  • The size of the sample
_incorrect.notFinal:
Incorrect. Two of the answers were correct:

  • The size of the sample

"a methodological process whereby an individual's records from multiple data sources are connected"

title: Time Series
body:
Many analytical publications use time series to publish data, such as in official statistics.

A time series is a set of time-ordered data, usually collected at regular intervals such as daily or monthly. An example of a time series in official statistics is the Consumer Prices Index (see graph below), a measure of inflation, which is collected monthly. 

With time series data, common analytical outputs may include analysis of trends, seasonal variation and forecasting. As a result, time series analysis can provide an insight into the effectiveness of government polices by evaluating changes over time.

title: Communicating analysis
body: What can you do to best support the correct interpretation when communicating analysis?

_items.text: Convey a range of possible outcomes
_items.feedback: All listed answers are correct.

_items.text: Explain how the level of uncertainty may affect the results
_items.feedback: All listed answers are correct.

_items.text: Consider a range of evidence from multiple sources
_items.feedback: All listed answers are correct.

Sir Ian Diamond is Head of the AF. He also holds other titles including the National Statistician and Head of the GSS.
Jenny Dibden is Head of the Government Social Research profession.

title: Consulting analysts
body: When should you consult with analysts?

_items.text: After designing the analysis, to get designs approved
_items.feedback: Incorrect, analysts will be able to guide you through the design process and give you an idea of what is feasible.
Incorrect, analysts can help you design methods for collecting data and with data collection itself.

Correct, consulting with analysts right at the beginning means that they can guide you on what is already available, what is feasible to collect (based on time, available resources etc) and help with designing, collecting and refining.

The Aqua Book covers guidance on carrying out, producing and quality assuring analysis. While this is relevant for evaluation, the Magenta Book covers specific guidance for evaluations of policy interventions.
Correct, the Magenta Book is a guidance document, advising on what to consider when designing and carrying out an evaluation.

body: A y-axis should always start at 0 on which kind of graph?

_items.feedback: Incorrect, a line graph can have a truncated y-axis without distorting the message. However, a bar graph should start at 0.
Correct, a bar graph should have a y-axis starting at 0 as otherwise it can distort the differences between bars.

title: New Component Title
body:
Thank you for taking this course. 

You should now have a better understanding of how to request, interpret and utilise analytical outputs. 

You can download a high-level summary of the course here to refer back to as notes. 

In this course we have covered: 

  • The Analysis Function
  • How analytical projects are designed
  • An overview of some key methodological techniques
  • The importance of quality at all stages of analysis
  • Thinking critically with data visualisations 
  • Communicating insight

If you are interested in further developing your analytical knowledge, take a look at the Analysis Function Learning Curriculum.

For any queries or comments about this resource, please contact the Analysis Function Team.

title: Feedback
body:
Please provide anonymous feedback for the course either below or in a new tab.

For any questions, or if you would like a response to your feedback or query, please contact the Analysis Function.

title: Summary
body:
This section has covered the early stages of the analysis lifecycle, these should be collaborative stages between the those requesting and those conducting the analysis, to ensure needs are balanced with potential outputs. 

Ensure you involve analysts early in this process, and allow time to engage with them. They are there to lead on analytical work and can help you incorporate analytical thinking throughout the project.

Before moving onto the third module (Methods of Analysis), you will be asked a few questions about your understanding of the "Asking analytical questions" module. 

More resources

Government Functional Standard for Analysis

Civil Service Learning: "Analysing evidence: effective collaboration" (note this has a policy-making focus)

Civil Service Learning: "Introduction to policy evaluation"

title: The purpose of data visualisations
body: What are the two main purposes of data visualisations?

_items.feedback: Correct, data visualisations are used for exploratory (gaining familiarity and understanding the dataset, variable or relationship) or explanatory purposes (communicating a particular message)

While data visualisations can be used to compare, the two main uses of data visualisations are for exploratory (gaining familiarity and understanding the dataset, variable and relationship) and explanatory (communicating/uncovering a particular message) purposes.

The two main purposes of data visualisationg are exploratory (gaining familiarity and understanding the dataset, variable or relationship) or explanatory purposes (communicating a particular message).

title: Data Collection
body:
There are many ways data can be sourced or collected. These can be qualitative or quantitative. 

Qualitative data is non-numerical, such as text, images or videos to answer broader, more open-ended questions. This does mean it can be subjective and difficult to produce generalisations with qualitative data. Meanwhile, quantitative data is numeric and measurable, allowing you to find correlations and relationships. You can use only qualitative or quantitative data, but they are often used in tandem to supplement the findings of the other.

_items.title: Census
_items.body:
A census aims to collect data from the entire population, with the 2021 Census receiving responses from 97% of households in England and Wales. This provides a high-quality snapshot of demographic data that other surveys can be compared against.

However, an operation like this requires substantial time and funding in order to plan, run and prepare results. For example, the work on the census between 2010 and 2021 was estimated to cost around £900m [ONS, 2021].

_items.title: Sample
_items.body:
Meanwhile, a sample selects a subset of the population of interest, and collects data from these individuals. The population of interest may be an entire country, or it may be a specific social group.

For example, the COVID-19 Infection Survey selects a smaller sample of the population and uses this to estimate antibody levels for the whole of the UK. As a sample requiring less time and resources than collecting information from the entire population, the results for this survey are published one week after data collection is complete. 

 

The quality of a sample depends on factors including: 

  • The size of the sample - increasing the size of the sample can increase the likelihood it will accurately represent the population
  • The sampling frame - what data was used to select participants?
  • Was the selection random - did each member of the population of interest have an equal chance of being selected?

 

In essence, we take a sample to produce as reliable estimates of the population of interest as possible with the resources available, rather than using a census. However, the sample, as a snapshot of the whole, can never perfectly represent the population, leaving some error or uncertainty.

_items.title: Administrative data
_items.body:
Administrative data, or admin data, is collected as the by-product of an organisational process, usually for operational reasons. For example, medical centers may collect information about the types of or reasons for interactions with their services for their own records. This data can then also be used for analytical research purposes.

As this data is collected as a by-product, it requires much fewer resources than collecting data via a survey and also may represent a greater portion of the population than a sample can. However, the methods used to collect data and the questions asked may not always align with the information needed for research purposes. Furthermore, it is also important to consider the reasons this data has been collected and how that may impact the reliability. An analyst should be able to discuss the suitability of various data sources with you. 

For example, Administrative Data Research Scotland are working on a project to analyse the impact of benefit sanctions, where claimants have their Job Seekers Allowance or Employment and Support Allowance reduced or stopped, on claimant's physical and mental health. In order to investigate this relationship, they are using multiple sources of administrative data including records of Job Seekers Allowance from the Department for Work and Pensions, as well as administrative records of interactions with health care services. You can read more about this project here.

_items.title: In-depth interviews
_items.body:
In-depth interviews are a qualitative method of data collection, where a structured and thorough conversation between an interviewer and interviewee can collect detailed information about individuals experiences and perceptions. Interviews are not the most suitable option where it is necessary to make generalisations about large groups of the population as they use small samples. However, they allow for much greater detail about complex issues involving perceptions and experiences. 

For example, the Department for Education conducted in-depth interviews with former teachers to investigate their reasons for leaving the role, as part of their efforts to improve retention rates. By using research to investigate this, they were better able to understand the multifaceted reasons for leaving the teaching profession. You can read more about this research and findings in the report.

_items.title: Focus groups
_items.body:
Focus groups use group dynamics to get shared experiences of people with similar characteristics. This is different from an interview study, where the focus is on individuals and the moderator should encourage the discussion of various viewpoints and perspectives. This allows for participants to be prompted by each others ideas and experiences. However, depending on the sensitive nature of the topic, you should consider whether participants will feel comfortable to discuss their experience in front of a group. 

They were used to collect data in research by the Office for National Statistics about children's wellbeing. Children aged 10-15 were asked to participate in focus groups discussing what they felt was necessary to lead a happy life. The findings of these focus groups were used to update the national indicators of children's wellbeing. You can read about this work here.

title: Daily COVID-19 cases dashboard
body:
There is also an interesting discussion of date selectivity in statistical trends on economic growth in this BBC "More or Less" podcast episode.

The second example of the importance of context is below. Looking only at the information in this line graph, it appears as though daily positive cases in the first lockdown (April 2020) were significantly lower than in the second lockdown (November 2020). However, the difference between these two periods is unlikely to be as drastic. 

While the below graph does include all collected data, these cannot always tell us the whole picture. In order to fully understand the data in this graph, you need to be aware of the context of testing capacity (number of daily tests for COVID-19 that could be carried out). Testing capacity was significantly increased over this period. At the end of April, the UK carried out around 30,000 tests a day, but by November this had increased to around 300,000 tests per day [source]. This means it is very likely that there was actually a much higher rate of positive cases in April, but there were not enough COVID-19 tests available to detect them all (note: testing is unlikely to be the sole reason for this difference, but is a main one).

Although this graph shows the true data, it also does not reflect the whole picture of positive cases. This highlights an important point around quality of data and data collection methods.

Ultimately, this means that this visualisation cannot solely be used to compare differences in the number of positive COVID-19 cases, additional information is required. One way in which best practice would support communicating this message would be for an annotation to be added to the chart, to explain changes in testing capacity and what impact this may have on the data points.

_graphic.alt: Government functional standard for analysis cover page

title: New Component Title
body:
This module has introduced you to the Analysis Function (AF) and who some of the analysts available to work with include.

To find out more about the AF, have a look through the Analysis Function website.

To find out more about each analyst role, you can explore the links  in each expandable section. Furthermore, there are even more analytical roles, which you can find out about with these role profiles.

Before moving on to the next module; "Asking analytical questions", you will be asked questions about the material you have just read.

title: Data Analyst
body: A Data Analyst aligns to which of the following professions?

_items.feedback: While a data analyst as an individual may feel they overlap with the DDaT profession, the data analyst role does not align to a profession.
While a data analyst as an individual may feel they overlap with the GSS, the data analyst role does not align to a profession.

_items.text: The data analyst role does not align with a profession.

_feedback.correct: The data analyst role does not align with a specific profession.

_incorrect.final: The data analyst role does not align with a specific profession.
_incorrect.notFinal: The data analyst role does not align with a specific profession.

_partlyCorrect.final: The data analyst role does not align with a specific profession.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: The data analyst role does not align with a specific profession.

title: Pre-Course Survey
body:
Please complete this survey before accessing the course content. 

You can do so below, or by opening the survey in a new tab.

title: Modelling
body:
Modelling is used in multiple analytical disciplines, such as data science (often called machine learning) or statistics (often called regression). Modelling is used to make predictions and detect relationships between variables using data. Essentially, a model is a simplified version of a real world relationship using mathematical equations. 

While you will not need to create your own models, it is important to understand that they are estimations and relevant measures of uncertainty, as discussed above, will apply. This means that any context or specific language provided by the analysts is essential to include when communicating the results.  

Below are some examples of how models have been used across government to support policy-making.

title: New Component Title
body:
The Data Science Campus (DSC) worked with the Welsh Government to produce a model that could make predictions. 

A gap in data providing energy ratings was identified for a large number of Welsh households. This makes it difficult to evaluate areas that need improvement in order to meet targets regarding climate change and emissions. 

However, the DSC were able to use pre-existing data to produce a model that can predict the energy rating for a household missing this data using information such as: 

  • the age of the property
  • the size of the property
  • the surroundings 

Making predictions for energy efficiency ratings in this way is much less resource-intensive than an expert completing a full survey on each household. This evidence will allow Welsh Government policy to be well-informed and understand the areas in need of development in order to meet net-zero targets. 

You can read more about this project in the DSC report.

title: Percentage difference vs. percentage point difference
displayTitle: Percentage difference vs. percentage point difference
body:
Two commonly confused or misunderstood concepts are percentage change and percentage point change. While both measures use percentages, they can hold very different values and so it is importance to understand and communicate the correct concept.

To outline the differences between these two concepts, a fictitious example of unemployment rate will be used below.

_items.body:
Lets say that in Year 1, the unemployment rate was 4% of the population or one million, three hundred and sixty four thousand people.​

Then in Year 2, the unemployment rate was 5% - or one million, seven hundred and five thousand people. ​

There are two ways we could use percentages to describe this change.

_graphic.alt: depicting data on unemployment, Year 1 is 4 percent or 1,364,000 and Year 2 is 5 percent or 1,705,000

_items.body: Firstly, by using percentage point difference. This describes a change in an already calculated percentage. In this example the unemployment rate has increased by one percentage point (from 4 percent to 5 percent of the total working age population) between Year 1 and Year 2. ​

_graphic.alt: visual depiction of moving from year 1 percentage to year 2 percentage

_items.body: The second option is to use percentage difference. This describes the change in the raw numbers, rather than the change in percentage.

_graphic.alt: visual depiction of year 1 and 2 raw figures/numbers

_items.body:
​

In the example, the number of individuals who are unemployed has increased by twenty five percent between Year 1 and Year 2. This was calculated by subtracting the rate for Year 1 from Year 2, then dividing that by the rate from Year 1 and finally, multiplying the answer by one hundred to create a percentage. 

Ultimately, both ways are valid in describing changes, but ensure you note the difference between percentage point (1 in this example) and percentage (25% in this example) change.

title: Introduction
body:
Performing analysis is primarily done for the insight it provides. In order to ensure that any outputs achieve the needs and expectations, thought and discussion between analysts and users will be needed to define the scope of the project. 

These analytical outputs can aid policy makers in making informed decisions, provide useful context to members of the public and can also look to explain the answer to the timeless question of 'so what'? Using evidence to analyse, for example, the impact of a policy, can help you quantify successes as well as areas that need further improvement or investment. 

Make sure you involve analysts early in this process - they are experts for a reason! They will be able to guide you through incorporating analytical thinking into your work. This includes reviewing what evidence is already available, and its quality or reliability, as well as discuss collecting further evidence and data. In addition, they can advise you on whether your expectations are realistic based on timescales, resources and explanatory power of the available evidence. 

Using insights from a range of analytical specialisms covered in the Analysis Function module will enable you to develop a rich and objective body of evidence.

title: Introduction
body:
Analytical literacy has been designed to support users of analysis, improving their ability and confidence to interact with analysts and analytical outputs.This is not about everyone being able to conduct analysis, this is about being able to work in partnership with analysts, interpret analysis and to use evidence to inform decisions.

This course will continue to develop over time, with new content being included. 

Course learning objectives:

  • Understand what the Analysis Function is and who is part of it
  • Be aware of the analysis lifecycle
  • Understand key analytical concepts/methods and how they can be used
  • Understand the key processes to assure high quality throughout the analytical process
  • Be able to think critically to draw out information from data visualisations 
  • Know what to consider when communicating analysis 

Overall, it should take you around two to three hours to work through these materials. This does not have to be done all in one go although you should make a note of your place in the course.

title: Index Numbers
body:
Index numbers are used to measure changes and to simplify comparisons. They can combine different types of data together, resulting in a single, summary value. This can be to compare changes over time, or between geographic locations, for example. A base time period, or location, is chosen and the value of the index at the base is assigned a value, usually 100. All data points are then given a value that represents the change compared to the base point.

One area where index numbers are commonly used is economics, where they can be used to measure the change in the prices or volume of goods and services. For example, a well-used index number is the Consumer Price Index, which measures inflation. Index numbers over time can be visualised in a time series, as displayed in the time series section above, sometimes called an index series.

title: Uncertainty
body:
Much of analysis is producing estimations, which revolve around chance. We are never absolutely certain that our analysis is correct or represents the entire population, there is always some level of possible error. Likewise, decisions made in the data collection process may reduce the accuracy of our analysis. However, there are many measures and procedures analysts can take to minimize uncertainty and provide figures to quantify the levels of uncertainty. To reduce uncertainty, it is important to prioritize quality throughout the analytical process from data collection to communication. Measures to ensure quality are discussed in more detail in the following module. 

It is essential that when reporting on analytical findings, or when these findings are used to draw conclusions or recommendations, that we also report on the associated estimated levels of uncertainty too.

To break down some of these measures, I will take an example from the COVID-19 Infection Survey report from the week ending 9th October 2021, which estimated: 

"890,000 people in England had COVID-19 (95% credible interval: 839,700 to 941,300)"

Expand each element below to find out more about that part of the reported finding.

_items.body: This is called a point estimate. This is a "best guess" for the value of some quantity. Sometimes you may only see the point estimate reported, but it is important to remember that this is an estimation.

_items.title: 839,700 to 941,300
_items.body:
While 890,000 is the best guess for the value, these figures a confidence interval, which is the range in which we expect the true value to fall within. 

Good practice is to report the range of possible values and not just the point estimate. A good way of communicating confidence intervals and the associated uncertainty is using data visualisations and graphs, where shaded areas are used to display confidence intervals.

_items.title: 95% credible interval
_items.body:
Depending on the type of analysis used, you may see the term "credible interval" or "confidence interval". 

These both have a similar purpose, but require slightly different interpretation. 

Firstly, a credible interval can be interpreted as there being a 95% chance that the true value lies within the range of estimated values. 

Meanwhile, a 95% confidence interval means that if we repeated the survey and analysis 100 times, 95 of those times would give us an answer within the same range as this one.

_items.title: Statistical significance
_items.body:
Statistical significance is used to decide whether our estimates reflect a true finding in the population, rather than random variation in our sample. 

Statistical significance helps to establish what observed changes or relationships we should pay attention to, and which apparent changes may have occurred only as a result of randomness. 

A result is said to be statistically significant if it is likely to not have been caused by chance.

Analysts can use measure such as credible or confidence intervals to make decisions about whether an estimate is statistically significant.

title: Designing the analysis
body:
Once the question has been well designed in the scoping stage, the analysis must be designed, bearing in mind it should: 

  • be able to answer the question posed
  • be proportionate to the question asked
  • represent good value for money 

There are many sources of data and analytical methods that can be used, and analysts will be able to pick out the most relevant. This may include data collection, policy-evaluation schemes etc. Analysts and stakeholders must engage with each other during this stage to agree objectives, resources, skills and timescales as much as possible. The analytical lifecycle allows for iteration and refinement, so the initial design should not be considered fixed, rather it should adjust to fit changing requirements. 

Some key requirements of all analytical work to be considered during the design stage are: 

  • repeatable: if another analyst was to perform the analysis again with the same inputs, the same results should be produced
  • impartial: the views or preconceptions of analysts or stakeholders should not be reflected in the output, the evidence should be factual and impartial
  • documented: keeping records of data and methods used for reproducibility or audit purposes
  • robust: able to be defended against any challenges or queries

It is also useful to consider theory of change at this point, a process of mapping from inputs to outcomes, encouraging analytical thinking and also prompting those involved to define measures for evaluating progress throughout the project. Theory of change is covered in more detail in the Introduction to policy evaluation course.

title: Introduction
body:
Users should feel assured that analytical outputs in government have been subject to various procedures and process guidelines to ensure they meet high standards of quality. 

There are procedures and guidance in place for each step of the analytical process, starting from data collection through to communicating.

title: Standards and guidance
body:
There are many standards, codes and guidance documents in place for those working in analysis across government. Some of these apply across professions and methods and others have been developed by individual professions and are relevant to specific types of analysis. 

Below are some examples of guidance existing across government, there are many more than it is possible to include here. You do not need to know the recommendations of all of these documents, but you should feel assured that they exist and encourage best practice, high quality and consistency throughout government analysis from the early data collection stage through to reporting or communicating. 

If you would like to read about each piece of guidance, you can expand the relevant section and/or visit the respective links.

_items.title: The Aqua Book
_items.body:
The Aqua Book provides advice on how to carry out, produce and quality assure analysis.

Some aspects of the guidance are aimed at those producing analysis, while others are aimed at those commissioning. For example, the guidance states "the person commissioning analysis must ensure that those doing the analysis understand the context of the question being asked".

_items.title: The Magenta Book
_items.body:
The Magenta Book is a guidance document, advising on what to consider when designing and carrying out an evaluation. 

It defines evaluation as "a systematic assessment of the design, implementation and outcomes of an intervention".

_items.title: The Orange Book
_items.body: The Orange Book covers the a principles-based approach that provides flexibility and judgement in the design, implementation and operation of risk management, informed by relevant standards and good practice.

_items.title: The Green Book
_items.body:
The Green Book from HM Treasury is guidance on how to appraise and evaluate policies, projects and programmes. 

The guidance is for all public servants involved in proposals for the use of public resources, not just analysts.

_items.title: Code of Practice for Statistics
_items.body:
The Code of Practice for Statistics outlines standards that Official Statistics are held against. Primarily, these are trustworthiness, quality and value. 

Other outputs may also voluntarily apply the principles outlined in the code.

_items.title: Government Functional Standard for Analysis
_items.body: The Government Functional Standard for Analysis sets out expectations and procedures for planning and carrying out analysis and applies across any analysis being carried out by or on behalf of government.

_items.title: Data Quality Framework
_items.body:
The Data Quality Framework outlines the principles, practices and tools aimed at achieving high quality, fit for purpose data. It applies to anyone working directly or indirectly with data.

There is also a Data Quality Hub in the Office for National Statistics, who work across government to improve data quality.

_items.title: Data Ethics Framework
_items.body: The Data Ethics Framework is guidance for anyone working directly or indirectly with data to support them in understanding ethical considerations. This means it also applies to those using analytical outputs.

_items.title: Quality Assurance of Code for Analysis and Research
_items.body:
The Quality Assurance of Code for Analysis and Research, sometimes called the DUCK book, was written by the Analysis Function and Government Statistical Service. 

It exists to support anyone across government using code or programming in their work, for example in statistical analysis or data science.

title: Context Matters
body: In some cases, creators of data visualisations may, intentionally or unintentionally, omit part of the data or omit a necessary explanation to provide context to the information shown. Below are two examples, the first where only a subset of the data is shown, and the second where all of the data is shown, but a key explanation for understanding the data is needed.
instruction: Use the arrows to navigate through each image

_items.body: This line graph was taken from a Daily Mail article about climate change and was used to draw a conclusion that there had been no overall change in average temperature. This was used to portray the message that climate change was progressing at a much slower rate than scientists have predicted.

_graphic.alt: line graph from a daily mail article stating that there have not been significant fluctuations in global temperature between 1997 and 2012

_items.body: However, if we look at the global average temperature data between 1850 and 2018 from the Met Office, it tells a very different story. Here there is a clear upward trend over time. Circled in red is the subset of the data used in the Daily Mail article.

_graphic.alt: Met office data on average global temperature between 1850 and 2018 showing overall upward trend

_items.body:
By only using a subset of data, while not incorrect, the article tells a distorted story around temperature increase. Furthermore, this data does not include temperatures in the polar regions, which show a steeper increase. 

This example shows the importance of using multiple sources of evidence before drawing a conclusion.

_graphic.alt: Repeat of daily mail temperature chart between 1997 and 2012

title: New Component Title
instruction: Click to open enlarged image in a new tab

title: Interpretation
instruction: By interpreting the information as shown in the graph, select all of the correct statements below:

_items.text: Retail sales were lowest in April 2020
_items.feedback: Correct, in the graph retail sales were at their lowest point in April 2020

_items.text: Retail sales have consistently decreased since July 2020
_items.feedback: Overall, retail sales have slightly increased since July 2020 despite a previous dip.

_items.text: Before February 2020, retail sales volumes were relatively stable
_items.feedback: Correct!

_items.text: Retail Sales were highest in October 2020
_items.feedback: Retail sales were highest in April 2021.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Retail sales reached their lowest point in April 2020, just after lockdown began.

Before February 2020, sales were relatively stable (although they were on a slight upward trend).

_incorrect.final:
Since July 2020, retail sales have both grown and fallen, they have not been consistently decreasing. 

Retail sales were actually highest in April 2021, exactly a year after they were at their lowest.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Some of your answers were correct. 

Retail sales reached their lowest point in April 2020, just after lockdown began.

Before February 2020, sales were relatively stable (although they were on a slight upward trend).
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Some of your answers were correct. 

Retail sales reached their lowest point in April 2020, just after lockdown began.

Before February 2020, sales were relatively stable (although they were on a slight upward trend).

title: Communicating Quality
body:
When interacting with or using analytical outputs from government, you should feel assured that these have gone through stringent processes and checks to ensure high quality. Effort should be made to include information about quality during any communication of insights drawn from analysis. These should detail the entire analytical processes from data collection to publication - poor quality at any stage reduces the quality and accuracy of the final results. 

However, all data sources and methods do inevitably have some pitfalls or limitations, none of them are perfect. In a report or official release, there should be technical reports or quality reports detailing the methods used and any limitations, so that producers are transparent and accountable and so users can see their quality. These should increase the impact of results, build trust in the insights generated and improve organisational reputation.

For example, when official statistics are released, it will be accompanied by a quality/technical report, often called a "Background Quality Report" (BQR). BQRs include detailed information on strengths, limitations and methods, particularly for technical experts.

title: What can you do to be confident in quality?
displayTitle: What can you do to be confident in quality?

_items.body: Review the quality/technical report to identify that there have been processes followed to assure quality
Ask the analyst or creator about how they ensured high quality throughout the process
Use multiple sources of evidence and confirm they are coherent
Ask for assurance there was not a conflict of interest of those producing the outputs
Give more weight to evidence you know is of high quality and lower weight to sources that you are unsure of the quality of or know has limitations

title: Evaluation
body:
Evaluation is a method commonly used across government to assess the effectiveness of policy interventions. As defined in the Magenta Book, “evaluation is a systematic assessment of the design, implementation and outcomes of an intervention”. There is an increasing encouragement to adopt evaluation across government to ensure increased impact of policy and value for money. Evaluation can support your programme and it's accountability at various stages from providing evidence to support design all the way through to supporting spending review applications.

Analysts should be involved early in the intervention design and evaluation design, to ensure it can be embedded throughout. Without involving analysts in the early stages, it is difficult to ensure that budgets are correctly ring-fenced for evaluation and that the right data is collected while carrying out the intervention.

The Home Office developed an intervention called the “Early Legal Advice Project”, which aimed to better support the right decisions being made in asylum seeking cases and reduce the number of appeals. However, by comparing the outcomes of a control group (with no intervention) with those in the Early Legal Advice Project, the evaluation found that the scheme did not have an impact on the proportion of cases being granted asylum but did increase discretionary leave. The findings of the evaluation meant that the intervention was not expanded more widely, which would have cost between £1.5-3.6 million.

Meanwhile, the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities launched the Rough Sleeping Initiative (RSI), targeting support at local authorities with high numbers of rough sleepers. The evaluation compared actual numbers of those sleeping rough with numbers that had been predicted before the interventions implementation. The findings of the evaluation were essential to make the case for further funding for similar initiatives, including a successful 2021 spending review bid. 

For further information, please explore the Evaluation guidance and resources document. Support for evaluation is available centrally via the Evaluation Task Force or the Analysis Function Evaluation Support team.

title: Introduction
body:
Drawing new insights is one of the primary reasons for collecting and producing analysis and being able to understand and effectively communicate this is key to making an impact. Analytical outputs support decision-makers in making robust, evidence-based decisions. It is important for this process to be collaborative throughout, between analysts and users to ensure expectations are achievable based on resource and explanatory power.

Understanding and interpreting analytical outputs are vital skills, and analysts are there to support you. Where analysis has been directly commissioned, at the reporting stage analysts and users should discuss whether the expectations outlined during the scoping and designing stages have been met.

title: What can you do?
body:
While the responsibility for communication of context and limitations of analysis lies primarily with the producer, a user of analysis should have an understanding of these concepts and share these more widely in work that uses analysis, particularly when used for a conclusion or recommendation. The importance of communicating these with all users is outlined in the Government Functional Standard for Analysis. While most of these fall on the analyst, users should also consider the below when sharing or using analysis:

  • being open and transparent about the sources of evidence and its limitations
  • convey the range of possible outcomes, rather than point estimates
  • use multiple sources and types of evidence to reach conclusions
  • consider a range of evidence impartially, giving weight based on quality or reliability, rather than to that which agrees with your presumptions
  • acknowledge that findings may portray correlation, but not that one measure has caused the other, unless clearly stated (see example below)
  • address how the level of uncertainty should affect the interpretation of the results or what can or cannot be concluded
  • attempt to pre-empt misunderstanding or over-interpretation

title: Summary
body:
This module has covered the importance of thinking about how findings will be read by users when sharing evidence with your audience. Do consider the limitations of the evidence you are using when you are making conclusions and ensure you share uncertainty alongside your findings.

More resources 

Government Statistical Service's "Writing about statistics"

Government Statistical Service's "Communicating quality, uncertainty and change"

Government Social Research's "Quality in Qualitative Evaluation"

Government Analysis Function's "Urgent data quality assurance guidance"

Data Quality Hub's "The importance of communicating data quality"

title: Correlation and causation
body:
While commonly confused, correlation and causation are not the same thing. It is very useful to be able to say that something happened because of something else, especially for policy evaluation. In practice, showing that something caused something else can be difficult. There is a big difference between showing that things are associated (correlation) and that one thing causes another (causation).

For example, research shows that the rate of shark attacks increases when the rate of ice cream sales increases. The two measures are correlated with each other. However, this is not because ice cream sales cause more shark attacks, in reality both are caused by higher temperatures and so increase at the same time, without either being caused by the other. 

Just because we have evidence that says two factors are changing in a similar way to each other, does not mean one has caused the other. In order to conclude that one factor has caused the other, we must have ruled out all other possible causes. 

It is really important to understand whether the analysis you use shows evidence of correlation or causation as this has a big impact on how you should communicate and interpret the results.

title: Designing the analysis
body: All analytical work should be:

_items.feedback: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.
Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.
Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.
Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.

_feedback.correct: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.

_incorrect.final: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.
_incorrect.notFinal: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.

_partlyCorrect.final: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Analytical work should be repeatable, impartial, documented and robust.

title: In-depth interviews
body: In-depth interviews collect which type of data?

_items.feedback: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.
In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.

_feedback.correct: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.

_incorrect.final: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.
_incorrect.notFinal: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.

_partlyCorrect.final: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: In-depth interviews collect qualitative data, often around experiences and perceptions.

title: BQR
body: What does BQR stand for?

_items.feedback: Incorrect, BQR stands for Background Quality Report.
Incorrect, BQR stands for Background Quality Report.
Correct, BQR stands for Background Quality Report.

title: The Analysis Lifecycle
body: At the very beginning of the process, discussion between analysts and commissioners or users is needed to determine the desired results. This is essential to the first two parts of the Analysis Lifecycle (pictured in the image on the right), as outlined in the Government Functional Standard for Analysis; scoping the analysis and designing the analysis. This cycle should be an iterative process, with plenty of communication between analysts and users, to establish any necessary refinements or changes.

title: Summary
body:
This module has covered the importance of assuring quality throughout all stages of the analytical process. This includes communicating quality or limitations when reporting on analysis. 

There are methods you can use to mitigate for quality limitations, such as using multiple sources evidence and ensuring coherence between them. If you are unsure on the quality or reliability of evidence, review technical reports or ask the producers for support. 

More resources 

Each code, practice or guidance is linked above in "Standards and guidance"

Civil Service Learning course: Quality, Evidence and Risk [account required]

Data Quality Hub course: Introduction to Data Quality
